Harkey looks at the drip irrigation system on one of the wine vineyards his company manages in Temecula in May. Harkey said unusual weather this year has affected crops. AGRICULTURE: Odd weather a burden for growers
A year’s worth of wild weather, leading into this weekend’s expected heatwave, has caused some headaches for area growers.
To start, 2015’s grape yield in the Temecula Valley was down, and the harvest happened much earlier than usual.
“Most of the grapes have already been picked,” said Krista Chaich, a representative for the Temecula Valley Winegrower’s Association. The harvest is usually finished around the end of October.
Now, the late-season high temperatures are playing havoc with avocado growers in the region.
J.D. Harkey, director of operations for Temecula-based Drake Enterprises, which manages production for various wineries and avocado farms, said hot weather means avocado trees need more water than they normally do this time of year. However, he said giving the trees more water is a difficult balancing act during a drought.
“We really have to be watching our allocations,” Harkey said. “You have to be very careful about how and when you use your water.”
Harkey said the fall heat is just the latest in a string of unusual weather events, from snow in January to sudden hot and cold spells spanning February through August. Drake Enterprises' grapes produced less than they normally do and they matured faster.
“I only had three varieties that produced average or above average yields,” Harkey said. “Anything else was a reduction of anywhere from 20 to 60 percent.”
Harkey said sugar and PH levels in the grapes harvested were normal, but it’s still too early to tell what the eventual outcome will be.
“Only time will tell if the wine from these grapes is negatively affected,” he said.
